content.description:
West Ridge has a high, funky crux at the last bolt with suspect rock...

caveat emptor

!

It is easy to avoid the crux.
content.location:
Start at the belay alcove with small pine tree, and traverse hard right (west) well past the start of

Moose Glades

, aiming for a micro, left-facing dihedral. Then head up aiming for a black dike of sorts higher on the wall. A big ledge separates the upper block (black dike) from lower slab.

content.description:
This is easier than

West Ridge

and less committing.
content.location:
Again, start at the belay alcove, enjoy the beautiful traverse out to the micro dihedral of

West Ridge

, and ascend but trend right at its top to another bolt.

content.description:
Start as with

Joan's Solitude

, but ease up and right to a large flake that takes a medium nut. Then step up to gain the slab and clip bolts as you climb staying to the right side of the slab.
content.protection:
6-7 (perhaps 5?) bolts, 1 medium wired nut needed.

Per

Dave Clark 5.10

: there are no spinning hangers as of 7/4/18.
content.location:
It was the farthest right on the slab.

Per

Dave Clark 5.10

: it is in the middle of the slab and goes up a rough, left-facing dihedral.

content.description: Moose Glades has fairly decent face climbing up into the dihedral.
content.location:
From the cozy little belay alcove with pine tree, traverse out right (west) to find the rising bolts to the right of

Salto Syllabic

, aiming for a bush and left-facing corner that rounds over into a ledge.

climbs.name: Minerva's Way
climbs.fa: Scott Allen, Tim Gale, Don Silver

content.location: Minerva's Way is located on a separate crag from the Eldora  Summer Slab. Find a marbled black and white pegmatite dike 300 feet left (east) and uphill from the Eldora Summer Slab.

content.description:
This is route is named in honor of Joan Henley O'Neall (1930-2013) who passed as I was creating this route.

This route ascends the center of the slab. Surmount the crux overhang and tip toe up the slab.
content.protection: 6-7 bolts and 1 medium wired nut. 2 bolt anchor at the top.
content.location:
This route lies in the center of the slab or the right of

Caucasian Sandal

.

content.description: This is a great swooping traverse under all the other routes! Traverse West to the end of the slab, and then climb up clear rock to a ledge. Continue upwards in the scooped out dishes and cracks above.
content.protection: 5 bolts (the last three are 1/4") and small nuts.
content.location:
This is the furthest route to the right (west).

Start from the same belay alcove, and traverse good rock above large CDOT anchors for steel netting.

content.description: This is the first route on the slab that was toproped and then bolted. Use the tree as needed or go stone direct. An optional left side start also works.
content.protection: 6-7 bolts (perhaps 5?) plus one small wired nut and one medium wired nut are required.
content.location: It is on the far right side of the slab, directly behind a pine tree.
